subcommands.name: agent
subcommands.description: listen on a vsocket for trace clients

flags.description: cid is the context ID (see vsock(7)) of the client (e.g., guest VM) it will allow to connect.

subcommands.name: attach
subcommands.description: attach a host trace.dat file to a guest trace.dat file

subcommands.name: check-events
subcommands.description: parse format strings for all trace events and return

subcommands.name: clear
subcommands.description: clear the content of the Ftrace ring buffers.

subcommands.name: convert
subcommands.description: convert trace files

subcommands.name: dump
subcommands.description: read out the meta data from a trace file

subcommands.name: extract
subcommands.description: extract the data from the kernel buffer and create a trace.dat

subcommands.name: hist
subcommands.description: show a histogram of the events.

subcommands.name: list
subcommands.description: list the available plugins or events that can be recorded.

subcommands.name: listen
subcommands.description: open up a port to listen for remote tracing connections.

subcommands.name: profile
subcommands.description: Start profiling and read the output directly

subcommands.name: record
subcommands.description: record a live trace and write a trace.dat file to the local disk or to the network.

flags.description: and . characters, then it will be parsed as a basic glob. to force it to be a regex, prefix the filter with ^ or append it with $ and it will then be parsed as a regex.
--temp can be used to tell trace-cmd where those temp files should be created.

subcommands.name: reset
subcommands.description: disables all tracing and gives back the system performance. (clears all data from the kernel buffers)

subcommands.name: restart
subcommands.description: restart tracing from a previous stop (only effects recording)

subcommands.name: restore
subcommands.description: restore the data files of a crashed run of trace-cmd record

flags.description: -k will override the file to read the kallsyms from. This can be useful if the trace.dat file to create is from another machine. Just copy the /proc/kallsyms file locally, and use -k to point to that file.

-t will use that location instead. This can be useful if the trace.dat file to create is from another machine. Just tar -cvf events.tar debugfs/tracing and copy and untar that file locally, and use that directory instead.

subcommands.name: set
subcommands.description: set a ftrace configuration parameter.

flags.description: *match to only filter functions that end with match. *match\* to only filter on functions that contain match.

subcommands.name: setup-guest
subcommands.description: create FIFOs for tracing guest VMs

subcommands.name: show
subcommands.description: display the contents of one of the Ftrace Linux kernel tracing files

subcommands.name: split
subcommands.description: splits a trace.dat file into smaller files.

subcommands.name: stack
subcommands.description: run and display the stack tracer

subcommands.name: start
subcommands.description: start the tracing without recording to a trace.dat file.

subcommands.name: stat
subcommands.description: show tracing (ftrace) status of the running system

subcommands.name: stop
subcommands.description: stop tracing (only disables recording, overhead of tracer is still in effect)

subcommands.name: stream
subcommands.description: Start tracing and read the output directly
